stories.title: An open-access database and analysis tool for perovskite solar cells

stories.text:
Ok so I just got to the magical level of 500 karma points on HN, unlocking the legendary downvote button.

But I do not like it, and I will in fact boycott it, vowing to never use it. Why you ask?

UX wise, it's too blunt and its purpose too vaguely defined. It resembles a "dislike" button.

Algorithm wise, it is too powerful, and seems like -4 points gives you a throttle (which actually means strangle) for a few hours.

Happened to me when I posted a smug (or?) remark on an OCaml post. Not gonna lie - going slightly out of line resulting in a hour-long "shut up" period felt very humiliating.

Everyone knows that a downvote is very powerful. Yet it's obvious that people use it against dissenting opinion. "I don't know why you're getting downvoted".

In a sense it becomes a kind of elitist power tool, earned by conforming to that silent but crushing pool of downvoters.

Speaking candidly, it therefor almost becomes like a social credit system, and deplatforms dissenting voices.

I'm not sure I can word it any better than this.

This is the problem. What is the solution?
stories.title: I'm boycotting the HN downvote button
